SubTopics: Solve multi-step real-life and mathematical problems posed with positive and negative rational numbers in any form (whole numbers, fractions, and decimals), using tools strategically. Apply properties of operations to calculate with numbers in any form; convert between forms as appropriate; and assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies.
Content: Joe’s mom gave him $40 for cutting their grass. He used the money to buy a $10.75 game and two snacks that cost $3.25 each. Joe also bought a bouquet of flowers for his mom.
If Joe went home with 1/4 of the money his mom gave him, how much did the flowers cost?

SubTopics: Understand that integers can be divided, provided that the divisor is not zero, and every quotient of integers (with non-zero divisor) is a rational number. If p and q are integers, then -(p/q) = (-p)/q = p/(-q). Interpret quotients of rational numbers by describing real-world contexts.
Content: Aiden and his two friends ordered a pizza with 12 slices. Together they ate 2/3 of the pizza. If they evenly divided what was left, how many slices would each of them receive?

SubTopics: Understand that statistics can be used to gain information about a population by examining a sample of the population; generalizations about a population from a sample are valid only if the sample is representative of that population. Understand that random sampling tends to produce representative samples and support valid inferences.
Content: Kate conducts a survey at her middle school to determine the students’ favorite sport. Which sampling method would BEST produce a representative sample of the population?

C.Choice: Kate surveys every fourth student entering the school.

D.Choice: Kate surveys every eighth student from a roster of the choir members.

SubTopics: Solve problems involving scale drawings of geometric figures, including computing actual lengths and areas from a scale drawing and reproducing a scale drawing at a different scale.
Content: Triangle 2 is a scale drawing of Triangle 1.
problems/MS22G7M/media/4a.jpg
Based on the information in the diagram, what is the length of side b?

SubTopics: Apply and extend previous understandings of addition and subtraction to add and subtract rational numbers; represent addition and subtraction on a horizontal or vertical number line diagram.
Content: Which expressions are equivalent to 1/3 – 2/5?
Select TWO answer choices.

SubTopics: Recognize and represent proportional relationships between quantities.
Content: The graph shows how many calories are in a store’s best­selling candy.
problems/MS22G7M/media/6a.jpg
Based on the graph, how many calories are in piece of candy?

SubTopics: Solve multi-step real-life and mathematical problems posed with positive and negative rational numbers in any form (whole numbers, fractions, and decimals), using tools strategically. Apply properties of operations to calculate with numbers in any form; convert between forms as appropriate; and assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies.
Content: Campbell’s paycheck was $257.20. She put 1/4 of her paycheck into a savings account and used 1/3 of what was left to pay bills.
How much money does she have remaining from her paycheck?

SubTopics: Use data from a random sample to draw inferences about a population with an unknown characteristic of interest. Generate multiple samples (or simulated samples) of the same size to gauge the variation in estimates or predictions.
Content: A company manufactures cell phones. In August, a random sample of 125 cell phones were inspected, and 3 phones were found to be defective. The company manufactured 8,000 cell phones in August.
Based on the results from the sample, about how many cell phones are expected to be defective?

SubTopics: Compute unit rates associated with ratios of fractions, including ratios of lengths, areas and other quantities measured in like or different units.
Content: Lee mows 1/3 of his lawn and uses 1/2 of a gallon of gas. What fraction of the lawn can he mow per gallon?

SubTopics: Apply properties of operations as strategies to add, subtract, factor, and expand linear expressions with rational coefficients.
Content: Identify the equivalent expression for each expression.

SubTopics: Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving the four operations with rational numbers.
Content: Jasmine walked 1/2 of a mile to school. After school, she walked 1/3 of a mile to her aunt’s house. Afterwards, she walked 5/6 of a mile home.
If Jasmine walks the same path every day, Monday through Friday, how many miles does she walk in 1 week?

SubTopics: Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving area, volume and surface area of two- and three-dimensional objects composed of triangles, quadrilaterals, polygons, cubes, and right prisms.
Content: Jessie is helping her grandmother plant a garden in the shape of the trapezoid shown.
problems/MS22G7M/media/12a.jpg
The garden will have the following dimensions:

:ibox:• Base one is 12.5 feet long.

• Base two is 0.5 times the length of base one.

• The height is 10 feet.
What is the area, in square feet, of this garden?

SubTopics: Use proportional relationships to solve multistep ratio and percent problems.
Content: Michael works in an electronics store. The manager tells Michael he wants to take 20% off a $495.00 television. If the television does not sell, the manager will again reduce the sale price by 25%. Michael tells the manager to reduce the original price by 45% because the sale price would be the same. Is Michael correct?

A.Choice: No, Michael’s method has a greater effect on the sale price.

B.Choice: No, the manager’s method has a greater effect on the sale price.

C.Choice: Yes, the sale price for both the manager’s method and Michael’s method is $272.25.

D.Choice: Yes, the manager’s method and Michael’s method both equal a 45% discount off the original price.

SubTopics: Understand that, just as with simple events, the probability of a compound event is the fraction of outcomes in the sample space for which the compound event occurs.
Content: Jaime rolls a number cube and spins a colored spinner. The spinner is divided into three equal sections. The tree diagram shows all the possible outcomes that can occur.
problems/MS22G7M/media/14a.jpg
Which statements are true? Select TWO answer choices.

A.Choice: The probability of Jaime rolling a 5 on the number cube and the spinner landing on red is 1/9.

B.Choice: The probability of Jaime rolling a 3 on the number cube and the spinner landing on blue is 1/6.

C.Choice: The probability of Jaime rolling a 2 or 3 on the number cube and the spinner landing on green is 1/18.

D.Choice: The probability of Jaime rolling a 1 on the number cube and the spinner landing on blue or green is 1/9.

E.Choice: The probability of Jaime rolling an even number on the number cube and the spinner landing on blue is 1/6.

SubTopics: Know the formulas for the area and circumference of a circle and use them to solve problems; give an informal derivation of the relationship between the circumference and area of a circle.
Content: What is the circumference of a circle with a radius of 4 inches? Use 3.14 for π.

SubTopics: Informally assess the degree of visual overlap of two numerical data distributions with similar variabilities, measuring the difference between the centers by expressing it as a multiple of a measure of variability.
Content: The dot plots show the math test scores from the sixth and seventh grade students.
problems/MS22G7M/media/16a.jpg
problems/MS22G7M/media/16b.jpg
Based on the dot plots, which statement correctly compares the two data sets?

A.Choice: The range of test scores in sixth grade is less than the range of test scores in seventh grade, and the mean test score in sixth grade is less than the mean test score in seventh grade.

B.Choice: The range of test scores in sixth grade is less than the range of test scores in seventh grade, and the mean test score in sixth grade is greater than the mean test score in seventh grade.

C.Choice: The range of test scores in sixth grade is greater than the range of test scores in seventh grade, and the mean test score in sixth grade is less than the mean test score in seventh grade.

D.Choice: The range of test scores in sixth grade is greater than the range of test scores in seventh grade, and the mean test score in sixth grade is greater than the mean test score in seventh grade.

SubTopics: Use variables to represent quantities in a real-world or mathematical problem, and construct simple equations and inequalities to solve problems by reasoning about the quantities.
Content: Mrs. Kimble earns $125per week working at a furniture store. For each piece of furniture she sells, Mrs. Kimble earns an additional $5. This week, she wants to earn more than $500.
If c is the number of pieces of furniture Mrs. Kimble sells, which inequality represents this situation, and what quantities are true for c?

SubTopics: Recognize and represent proportional relationships between quantities.
Content: The graph shows the relationship between the weight of pears and the total cost of the pears.
problems/MS22G7M/media/18a.jpg
What does point A on the graph represent?

C.Choice: The cost of 1 pound of pears is $2.00.

D.Choice: The cost of 4 pounds of pears is $2.00.

SubTopics: Understand that rewriting an expression in different forms in a problem context can shed light on the problem and how the quantities in it are related.
Content: A store marks up the merchandise it receives from the manufacturer by 25%. Which expressions can be used to determine the price the store charges when the manufacturer charges m dollars?
Select TWO answer choices.

SubTopics: Describe the two-dimensional figures that result from slicing three-dimensional figures, as in plane sections of right rectangular prisms and right rectangular pyramids.
Content: A right rectangular pyramid is shown.
problems/MS22G7M/media/20a.jpg
What two­dimensional figure results from vertically slicing the pyramid from its apex to its base?

SubTopics: Compute unit rates associated with ratios of fractions, including ratios of lengths, areas and other quantities measured in like or different units.
Content: Ryan completed 1/8 of his test in 2/5 of an hour. If Ryan’s rate stayed the same, how much of his test was finished in 1 hour?

SubTopics: Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving the four operations with rational numbers.
Content: What is the value of the expression (x + 60)/2 for each value of x?
Correctly match each value.

SubTopics: Use measures of center and measures of variability (i.e. inter-quartile range) for numerical data from random samples to draw informal comparative inferences about two populations. For example, decide whether the words in a chapter of a seventh-grade science book are generally longer than the words in a chapter of a fourth-grade science book.
Content: Dave completed a random sample of fish from two ponds. The results are shown.
problems/MS22G7M/media/23a.jpg
Based on the samples, which statement BEST compares the lengths of the fish in each pond?

A.Choice: The fish in Pond A are generally longer and have less variability in length than the fish in Pond B.

B.Choice: The fish in Pond A are generally longer and have greater variability in length than the fish in Pond B.

C.Choice: The fish in Pond A are generally shorter and have less variability in length than the fish in Pond B.

D.Choice: The fish in Pond A are generally shorter and have greater variability in length than the fish in Pond B.

SubTopics: Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving area, volume and surface area of two- and three-dimensional objects composed of triangles, quadrilaterals, polygons, cubes, and right prisms.
Content: Mr. Thomas owns a rectangular property that is 52 feet long and 35 feet wide. He adds a new triangular property directly behind his existing property. The base length of the triangular property is equal to the length of the rectangular property. An aerial view of the whole property is shown.
problems/MS22G7M/media/24a.jpg
The area of the whole property is 2,600 square feet. Based on the diagram, what is the maximum height, in feet, of the triangular property?

SubTopics: Apply properties of operations as strategies to add, subtract, factor, and expand linear expressions with rational coefficients.
Content: Which expression is equivalent ot –2(x + 4) – (3x + 8)?

SubTopics: Understand that the probability of a chance event is a number between 0 and 1 that expresses the likelihood of the event occurring. Larger numbers indicate greater likelihood. A probability near 0 indicates an unlikely event, a probability around 1/2 indicates an event that is neither unlikely nor likely, and a probability near 1 indicates a likely event.
Content: Ms. Evan allows her students of the week to spin a reward wheel. The reward wheel is shown.
problems/MS22G7M/media/26a.jpg
What is the likelihood of landing on the 5-point bonus section?

SubTopics: Use proportional relationships to solve multistep ratio and percent problems.
Content: Kelsey opened a savings account 6 years ago that earns 1.2% simple interest every year. She started the account with $600 and has not touched the account since. How much money is in the account now?

SubTopics: Use facts about supplementary, complementary, vertical, and adjacent angles in a multi-step problem to write and solve simple equations for an unknown angle in a figure.
Content: Line ma and line n are parallel. They are intersected by line p as shown.
problems/MS22G7M/media/28a.jpg
What is the measure of ∠Q?

SubTopics: Approximate the probability of a chance event by collecting data on the chance process that produces it and observing its long-run relative frequency, and predict the approximate relative frequency given the probability.
Content: A number cube that has sides numbered 1 through 6 is rolled 180 times.
The following question has two parts. First, answer Part A. Then, answer Part B.
How many times would you expect the result to be an even number greater than 2?
How many times would you expect the result to be a number less than 6?

SubTopics: Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving the four operations with rational numbers.
Content: As part of a science experiment, Sam measured the amount of rainfall, in inches, over the course of a week. A table of the measurements Sam collected is shown.
problems/MS22G7M/media/30a.jpg
What was the mean amount of rainfall, in inches, over the course of the week?

SubTopics: Use facts about supplementary, complementary, vertical, and adjacent angles in a multi-step problem to write and solve simple equations for an unknown angle in a figure.
Content: Angles ABC and CBD are supplementary angles. The measure of ∠ABC can be represented by the expression (3x + 14)°, and the measure of ∠CBD can be represented by the expression (5x + 6)°.
What is the measure, in degrees, of ∠ABC?

SubTopics: Recognize and represent proportional relationships between quantities.
Content: Match the relationship shown in each table with its corresponding equation.

SubTopics: Understand that rewriting an expression in different forms in a problem context can shed light on the problem and how the quantities in it are related.
Content: A cell phone company is giving a 20% discount on all phone accessories. Which expressions can be used to find the sale price of an item with an original price of x dollars?
Select TWO answer choices.

SubTopics: Informally assess the degree of visual overlap of two numerical data distributions with similar variabilities, measuring the difference between the centers by expressing it as a multiple of a measure of variability.
Content: The box plots compare the gross earnings, in millions of dollars, of movies during the months of August and November.
problems/MS22G7M/media/34a.jpg
Which statement correctly compares the two data sets?

A.Choice: The median in August is about half of the median in November.

B.Choice: The median in November is about 400 more than the median in August.

C.Choice: The difference in the medians is about half of the range in November.

D.Choice: The difference in the medians is about half of the interquartile range in August.

SubTopics: Use variables to represent quantities in a real-world or mathematical problem, and construct simple equations and inequalities to solve problems by reasoning about the quantities.
Content: Every day of the week, Jordan $4 earns per hour for delivering newspapers. She also earns a weekly bonus of $10 if she arrives on time to work each day.
Last week, Jordan arrived on time to work every day and earned a total of $96 for h hours of work. Based on this situation, which statement is true?

A.Choice: Jordan worked a total of 4 hours.

B.Choice: Jordan worked a total of 9 1/4 hours.

C.Choice: Jordan worked a total of 10 hours.

D.Choice: Jordan worked a total of 21 1/2 hours.

SubTopics: Know the formulas for the area and circumference of a circle and use them to solve problems; give an informal derivation of the relationship between the circumference and area of a circle.
Content: A school’s art teacher designs a circular flower bed inside a rectangular sandbox. The sandbox is 6 feet wide and 10 feet long.
problems/MS22G7M/media/36a.jpg
How many square feet of sand will there be after the flower bed is installed? Use 3.14 for π. Round the answer to the nearest square foot.

SubTopics: Understand that the probability of a chance event is a number between 0 and 1 that expresses the likelihood of the event occurring. Larger numbers indicate greater likelihood. A probability near 0 indicates an unlikely event, a probability around 1/2 indicates an event that is neither unlikely nor likely, and a probability near 1 indicates a likely event.
Content: Which event is most likely to occur?

A.Choice: tossing a fair coin and landing on heads

B.Choice: spinning a 3 on a spinner divided into 4 equal sections numbered 1 through 4

C.Choice: picking a red marble from a bag of marbles that contains 3 blue, 4 red, and green 2 marbles

D.Choice: rolling a number cube that has sides numbered 1 through 6 and landing on a number less than 5

SubTopics: Use variables to represent quantities in a real-world or mathematical problem, and construct simple equations and inequalities to solve problems by reasoning about the quantities.
Content: Two rectangular properties share a common side. Lot A is 33 feet wide and 42 feet long.
problems/MS22G7M/media/38a.jpg
The combined area of the lots is 1,848 square feet. How many feet wide is Lot B?

SubTopics: Apply properties of operations as strategies to multiply and divide rational numbers.
Content: What is the value of the expression –2(–7/9 ÷ 1/3)?

SubTopics: Approximate the probability of a chance event by collecting data on the chance process that produces it and observing its long-run relative frequency, and predict the approximate relative frequency given the probability.
Content: Jamie spun a colored spinner 20 times. The results of her spins are shown in the frequency table.
problems/MS22G7M/media/40a.jpg
Based on the data in the table, how many times should Jamie expect the spinner to land on green if she spun the spinner 400 times?

SubTopics: Draw (freehand, with ruler and protractor, and with technology) geometric shapes with given conditions. Focus on constructing triangles from three measures of angles or sides, noticing when the conditions determine a unique triangle, more than one triangle, or no triangle.
Content: Which conditions will result in the construction of a unique triangle?
Select TWO answer choices.

SubTopics: Use measures of center and measures of variability (i.e. inter-quartile range) for numerical data from random samples to draw informal comparative inferences about two populations. For example, decide whether the words in a chapter of a seventh-grade science book are generally longer than the words in a chapter of a fourth-grade science book.
Content: A random sample of the girls’ heights at a basketball camp is shown.
problems/MS22G7M/media/42a.jpg
Based on the data, select the box that indicates whether each statement is true or false.

SubTopics: Understand that multiplication is extended from fractions to rational numbers by requiring that operations continue to satisfy the properties of operations, particularly the distributive property, leading to products such as (–1)(–1) = 1 and the rules for multiplying signed numbers. Interpret products of rational numbers by describing real-world contexts.
Content: Oliver is trying to keep up with the current amount of money in his bank account. He uses positive numbers to show his deposits and negative numbers to show his withdrawals.
Which expression BEST represents Oliver making 8 withdrawals of 25 dollars?

SubTopics: Develop a probability model (which may not be uniform) by observing frequencies in data generated from a chance process.
Content: A spinner is spun 20 times, and the number of times the arrow lands on each color is recorded. The table shows the results.
problems/MS22G7M/media/44a.jpg
Based on the results, what is the probability the next spin will be blue or green?

SubTopics: Know the formulas for the area and circumference of a circle and use them to solve problems; give an informal derivation of the relationship between the circumference and area of a circle.
Content: Shawn is placing a fence around a circular garden with a 15-foot diameter. How many feet of fencing will Shawn need to buy to enclose the garden? Use 3.14 for π. Round the answer to the nearest foot.

SubTopics: Represent sample spaces for compound events using methods such as organized lists, tables and tree diagrams. For an event described in everyday language (e.g., “rolling double sixes”), identify the outcomes in the sample space which compose the event.
Content: Raul has a fair coin and a spinner divided into four congruent sections labeled A, B, C, and D. Raul will toss the coin once and then spin the spinner.
Which tree diagram shows all the possible outcomes?

SubTopics: Develop a uniform probability model by assigning equal probability to all outcomes, and use the model to determine probabilities of events.
Content: A stack of cards are numbered from 1 through 50. If a student selects a card, what is the probability that the student will select a card that has both the same number in the ones place and the tens place? Write the answer as a decimal.

SubTopics: Solve multi-step real-life and mathematical problems posed with positive and negative rational numbers in any form (whole numbers, fractions, and decimals), using tools strategically. Apply properties of operations to calculate with numbers in any form; convert between forms as appropriate; and assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies.
Content: Ken earned $128 from his part­time job this summer. He spent 25% of his money on games. He is going to donate 1/6 of the remaining money to charity. How much money will the charity receive?

SubTopics: Recognize and represent proportional relationships between quantities.
Content: Employees at an arcade are paid according to the number of hours worked, as shown in the graph.
problems/MS22G7M/media/49a.jpg
Based on the graph, which statements are true?
Select THREE answer choices.

A.Choice: If employees do not work, they earn $7.25.

B.Choice: If employees work for 1 hour, they earn $7.25.

C.Choice: If employees work for 4 hours, they earn $29.00.

D.Choice: If employees work for 10 hours, they earn $73.00.

E.Choice: If employees work for 3.5 hours, they earn $21.75.

F.Choice: If employees work for 7.25 hours, they earn $1.00.

G.Choice: If employees do not work, they do not earn any money.

SubTopics: Convert a rational number to a decimal using long division; know that the decimal form of a rational number terminates in 0s or eventually repeats.
Content: Identify the equivalent decimal of each fraction.

SubTopics: Approximate the probability of a chance event by collecting data on the chance process that produces it and observing its long-run relative frequency, and predict the approximate relative frequency given the probability.
Content: A fair number cube, with numbers 1 through 6, was rolled 200 times. The number 5 was 34 rolled times. If the number cube was rolled 300 times, APPROXIMATELY how many times would the number 5 be rolled?

SubTopics: Use facts about supplementary, complementary, vertical, and adjacent angles in a multi-step problem to write and solve simple equations for an unknown angle in a figure.
Content: A diagram is shown.
problems/MS22G7M/media/52a.jpg
What is the measure of ∠CED?

SubTopics: Use variables to represent quantities in a real-world or mathematical problem, and construct simple equations and inequalities to solve problems by reasoning about the quantities.
Content: Chris works at a bookstore and earns $7.50 per h hour plus a $2 bonus for each book she sells. Chris sold 15 books. She wants to earn a minimum of $300.
Which inequality represents this situation, and what quantities are true for h?

SubTopics: Apply and extend previous understandings of addition and subtraction to add and subtract rational numbers; represent addition and subtraction on a horizontal or vertical number line diagram.
Content: Which situation results in a solution of 0?

A.Choice: Nicole walked 10 blocks north from her house to a friend’s house. After visiting, Nicole walked 10 blocks south back to her house. How far was Nicole from her starting place?

B.Choice: Shawn earned $42 from babysitting last Friday night. On Saturday, Shawn earned another $42 from babysitting. How much money did Shawn earn from babysitting?

C.Choice: The record low temperature in a city is –12 degrees. Today, the temperature is 12 degrees. What is the difference between the record low and today’s temperature?

D.Choice: A building has 5 floors above ground and 5 floors below ground. An elevator descended 5 floors below ground. The elevator then rose 5 floors. How far was the elevator from the top floor?

SubTopics: Solve multi-step real-life and mathematical problems posed with positive and negative rational numbers in any form (whole numbers, fractions, and decimals), using tools strategically. Apply properties of operations to calculate with numbers in any form; convert between forms as appropriate; and assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies.
Content: The windows of a school bus need to be washed by the end of the day. Mr. Casey washes 1/3 of the 33 windows before lunch. If Mr. Casey 8 washes of the remaining windows after lunch, how many windows still need to be washed by the end of the day?

SubTopics: Solve problems involving scale drawings of geometric figures, including computing actual lengths and areas from a scale drawing and reproducing a scale drawing at a different scale.
Content: Sam drew △ABC, then applied a scale factor of 2 1/3 to draw △QRS.
problems/MS22G7M/media/56a.jpg
problems/MS22G7M/media/56b.jpg
What are the side lengths of △QRS? Select the box in each row that identifies the correct value for each side.

SubTopics: Apply and extend previous understandings of addition and subtraction to add and subtract rational numbers; represent addition and subtraction on a horizontal or vertical number line diagram.
Content: At 11:00 p.m., the temperature in Alaska was –5°. Four hours earlier, the temperature was 40° warmer. What was the temperature at 7:00 p.m.?

SubTopics: Solve problems involving scale drawings of geometric figures, including computing actual lengths and areas from a scale drawing and reproducing a scale drawing at a different scale.
Content: Jim drew a triangle with side lengths, in inches, of 3 1/2, 4 3/4, and 5 9/10. Riley made a scale drawing of Jim’s triangle using a scale factor of 1/6.
Which list shows the side lengths, in inches, of the triangle Riley drew?

SubTopics: Recognize and represent proportional relationships between quantities.
Content: Which table represents a proportional relationship?

SubTopics: Develop a uniform probability model by assigning equal probability to all outcomes, and use the model to determine probabilities of events.
Content: A middle school is having a raffle for a laptop. The school will draw the winning ticket once all 450 tickets have been sold. Mark bought 5 tickets.
The following question has two parts. First, answer Part A. Then, answer Part B.
What is the probability of winning the laptop if one ticket is purchased? Express the answer as a decimal rounded to the nearest thousandth.
What is the probability that Mark will win the laptop? Express the answer as a decimal rounded to the nearest hundredth.

SubTopics: Understand that rewriting an expression in different forms in a problem context can shed light on the problem and how the quantities in it are related.
Content: Charlie’s Pancake House has decided to increase all of its menu prices by 8%. Let x represent the original price of an item on the menu. Which expressions can the owner use to calculate each item’s new menu price?
Select TWO answer choices.
